It really upsets me to see just how truly ignorant some people are about science. Still at this day in age. Especially in the fields of mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology, medicine, philosophy, psychology and cosmology. Always making false assumptions due to a sheer lack of knowledge in the particular subject you are commenting about. It's great that you are asking these questions, but please, for the love of god do not ask them in a comment on a youtube video. You will NEVER get the response you're looking for. Instead, go talk to your nearest teachers, academia professors, professionals in the work field, people with the experience and knowledge to help answer any question you may have. If you can't do that, then go to professional scientific forums where many PhD/Graduate students and degree holders would be gladly to answer your questions there too. 

As a third year Chemistry major, who has a complete love for understanding the world we live in, it pains me to see the only thing people seem to care about are answers to particular questions in which we are unable to answer at this point in time.We are all looking for answers, yes, but at this point in time, we are unable to do so. So arguing about it over and over and over and over again is just pointless. It isn't going to advance progress any faster by doing so. 

The beauty of science is truly remarkable. Take water for example. H2O. What do we know about water? Well, to most, we know that it covers nearly 3/4 of our planet, we are able to swim in it, we are able to drink, we know it changes phases depending on temperature and we know it's also essential to maintain normal biological functions throughout our bodies.

To chemists however, water is so much more than what I described above. Take a water molecule for example. Oxidation states, Chemical bonding, Polarity and Net dipole moments, Molecular geometry and Bond angles, Molecular Orbital diagrams, Hydrogen bonding, Wavefunctions, Phase changes, Triple and Critical points, Orbital density functions, Frontier orbital interactions,Thermal conductivity, Solubility, Entropy, Enthalpy, Amphoterism, Acidity and Basicity are all properties that chemists used to explain the nature of water.

 A Biochemist, on the other hand, could tell you how water functions inside the body. 

Physicists use Physics and Mathematics (mostly vector calculus and differential equations) to explain the kinematics and dynamics of fluid flow (or the way in which liquids (or water in this case) moves through time and space). 

The point is that what people think they may know about something that seems to be common knowledge (such as knowing what water actually is, how it's important to everyday life, and how describing it's motion can be used to solve various problems throughout various fields of engineering to help benefit modern day human life) may in fact be actually something they could learn and benefit a lot from. Never stop asking questions. Just go about asking them in the right way. Thank you.

theres so many good questions, I just don't know what to answer.  Yes, we are indeed sure of the "existence" of this antimatter.  Lets take what I view to be the simplest one,  the positron.

Typically atoms have a neutral charge.  If you have, say an atomic core comprised of say, 7 protons,  well then normally youll find (when you add up all the orbiting rings) 7 electrons orbiting it balancing it out. 

if you have say, one lonely proton with no electron balancing out the charge, that ABSENCE of an electron equates to essentially a positive charge.  This protons wanting of an electron is what we would call a "positron" which again has a positive charge.  If the proton can just manage to find a spare electron, balance will be restored, and as the universe would have it,  energy constantly seeks equilibrium.  Be it thermic, atomic, whatever.

If anyone is wondering why photons are their own antiparticle with a 0 charge, but neutrinos are not, that was unexplained in this video.
Basically, each lepton has a special "lepton number" that is used in equivalence equations, like with conservation of energy. The leptons (electron, tau, and muon), have their associated neutrinos (electron neutrino, tau neutrino, and muon neutrino) with the same lepton number, but no charge. When a muon decays into an electron, it also needs to release a muon neutrino to preserve the muon lepton number (at its original 1), the aforementioned electron, and an anti-electron neutrino in order to preserve the electron lepton number (at its original 0).

So, even though the neutrino has no charge, its anti particle doesn't only have opposite charge; it also has an opposite lepton number. This is true for all leptons. Quarks have something similar with anti-colors.

Here's my take: The Big Bang contained equal amounts of both matter and antimatter, but, as is the nature of randomness, it wasn't evenly spread. Let's say for the sake of argument that the left side of the Big Bang just happened to contain more matter than antimatter, and the right side contained more antimatter.

On the left side of the universe, matter and antimatter kept annihilating each other until there was only matter left. The opposite happened on the right side. Now, one half contains only matter, and the other only antimatter, and there's much less stuff than there was when the Big Bang happened.

As the universe expands, every particle of matter that is travelling right is eventually obliterated, same for every particle of antimatter travelling left. And so, in a stable universe, the universe spreads one way, whereas the anti-universe spreads the other, and they just go further and further apart.

If we could FIND antimatter, we would already have been destroyed by it; the reason we don't find it is because the universe has existed for a long time and has become pretty stable by now.

As far as I can tell, there's only two real option - either equal amounts of matter and antimatter were produced in the big bang, and for some reason some regions of the universe are more dense with one than the other (with the other regions being too far away too observe due to the speed of light being a thing); or slightly more of one than the other was produced (which one isn't important, since it's all perspective), in which case a small difference over a LOT of initial stuff could account for all we observe.

On the one hand, we've never observed a closed process that started and ended with different proportions of matter and antimatter; on the other hand, that doesn't mean such a process couldn't exist, especially in the early universe where the fundamental forces were apparently involved in some weird super-symmetries. The breaking of those super-symmetries at certain energy levels could, potentially, be the mechanism for the imbalance - but that gets into all kinds of theoretical stuff.

There was once the same amount matter and antimatter in the universe. The problem is that once the universe started to expand, and therefore cool down, the energy required to acheive 'pair production' and other interactions leading to the formation of antimatter (and matter) was never reached again. This energy, according to Boltzman's equation, is E = 3/2kT, where k is Boltzman's constant (1,38 x 10^(-23) JK(-1)) and T is temperature in Kelvin. Provided that the magnitude order of k is so small, in order to create an electron-positron pair, extremely high temperatures (ridiculously high) are required. So when the Unierse no longer was at that temperature, no more of these interactions took place. In theory, there should be the same amount of matter as of antimatter (we're talking of 10^(-35) seconds after the supposed Bang. However, as these particles started to decay, antiparticles decayed at a much faster rate. This lead to the particle era (10^(-12) seconds after the Bang) at 10^15 Kelvin. The temperature drop allowed the formation of the first nuclei, and later on, atoms. Larger elements were formed due to the nuclear reactions inside stars (which formed from condensed dust clusters). Nowadays, antimatter is scarce in our universe. Sorry for this humongous text :)

Isn't the standard explanation for why there is more matter than antimatter something like the following? There are two types of particles: type A and type B, with type A being identical to type B in all ways aside from having an opposite charge. The big bang created slightly more of one type, let's say type A. A lot of annihilation happened. What's left is the "surplus" type A, and a little bit of type B that hasn't had the chance to annihilate yet. We appear and start calling type A "matter" and type B "antimatter". But had it happened that type B was more prevalent in the first place, we'd have called type B "matter" and type A "antimatter', and our classical physicists would have explained the atom as a cloud of positive charged light particles orbiting a negatively charged core.
